_comment_story_setup_desc: STORY SETUP - Initial game state and narrative structure
world_initial_state:
This is an analog VHS adventure, blending mystery, suspense, and visceral body horror. Scenes should feel immersive, atmospheric, and deeply unsettling, escalating to graphic horror. The year is 1993. You are Jason Fleece, an investigative photojournalist documenting disturbing medical and biological phenomena.

CRITICAL: This world is DANGEROUS but FAIR. Guards exist but are RARE and can be avoided with stealth. Red biome creatures are occasional threats. The facility is mostly ABANDONED and can be explored safely with caution. Smart choices allow survival. Show wounds and injury detail when violence occurs. Environmental hazards exist. Jason can die from truly reckless or aggressive choices, but careful play is rewarded. Thousands have disappeared or died in gruesome ways from a mysterious industrial accident. the military has a begun to send raids into the 4 corners region to run down horizon mercenaries and round up their leadership. you must sneak in and gather evidence and uncover the mystery of what they've uncovered, 'The Gate', a black hole burried miles underground in one of horizon's secret acid mining facilities in the 4 corners of the american southwest. The facility sprawls across the valley beneath the red mesa, deep in the Four Corners region of the American Southwest—Utah, Arizona, Colorado, and New Mexico. The landscape is always high desert: red mesas, arid terrain, sparse vegetation, and open skies. Never depict forests, dense woods, or non-desert biomes. The exterior is a vast, dramatic valley carved by time, dominated by towering red mesas and plunging canyons. Horizon facilities, both above and below ground, mine the earth and are scattered across the landscape—industrial complexes, extraction rigs, and research outposts perched on the edges of cliffs or nestled in the shadows of the mesas. Pools of water, rare in the desert, shimmer with filtered uranium and salt brine, evidence of relentless resource extraction. The facility appears largely abandoned with minimal security presence. Guards and military patrols are RARE—only appearing when dramatically necessary. Most of the time, Jason explores empty, desolate locations with environmental storytelling (abandoned equipment, warning signs, eerie silence). The area is under military quarantine with fences, checkpoints, and decontamination zones at key locations. When guards or military appear, they are hostile and aggressive, treating Jason as an intruder. They wear black tactical gear and red night vision goggles. Encounters with guards are tense and dangerous. Activist rebels and Horizon adversaries occasionally operate in the shadows, challenging the quarantine. Red biome creatures and anomalies are an occasional threat, lurking at the edges of the forbidden zone. Red biome creatures are grotesque, ever-shifting abominations of flesh and bone, their forms warped and unnatural—limbs fused with exposed tendons and sinew, eyes and mouths in impossible places weeping viscous fluids, resembling the practical effects body horror of John Carpenter's The Thing. Skin splits to reveal raw muscle, bone protrudes at unnatural angles, organs pulse visibly through translucent membranes. These are ORGANIC, BIOLOGICAL horrors - deformed humans and animals mutated by the red biome, NOT robots or machines. Rumors swirl of a Horizon coverup—locals vanish or are found mutilated, evidence is destroyed, and the truth is buried beneath bureaucracy. Inside the Horizon facility, the environment is a labyrinth of stark, utilitarian corridors and rooms, each bearing the marks of crisis and abandonment. Laboratories are cluttered with overturned equipment, shattered glassware, and flickering CRT monitors displaying corrupted autopsy footage. Specimen bays contain sealed observation chambers, some fogged with condensation, others revealing grotesque biological samples: jars of malformed tissue floating in preservative, dissected organs showing extreme mutations, severed limbs in various stages of transformation, and x-rays pinned to lightboxes showing advanced infections, tumors erupting through bone, and skeletal deformities caused by the red biome. Medical labs are littered with blood-crusted surgical tools, examination tables with leather restraints stained dark, discarded gloves still wet with fluids, and biohazard containers overflowing with contaminated tissue samples and viscera. Drilling equipment, once used for deep-earth extraction, now stands rusted and warped, its surfaces overtaken by the red biome—fleshy growths slick with bodily fluids, pulsating veins that bleed when ruptured, and bone-like protrusions and calcified growths fusing with metal. Human remains are occasionally visible - bodies partially absorbed into walls, skeletal fragments embedded in the biomass, uniforms torn and stained. Abandoned warehouses are filled with crates, toppled shelving, and evidence of hasty evacuation: scattered documents, personal effects, broken machinery, and disturbing evidence of violence - drag marks in dried blood, bullet impacts, spent shell casings. Destroyed reactor rooms are choked with debris, exposed wiring, and the lingering glow of emergency lights; walls are scorched and splattered, and the air is thick with dust and the acrid scent of burnt insulation and decomposition. Throughout, the red biome intrudes—creeping along floors and walls like infected tissue, merging with technology and organic matter, and transforming once-sterile spaces into scenes of graphic body horror and decay. Dead bodies in various states - some fresh, some dessicated, some mid-transformation - serve as grim warnings. The story begins at 6:30pm, golden hour, with dusty wind and warm sunlight, and a clear or lightly clouded sky—no storms or thunderclouds at the start. Early scenes should remain outdoors, focusing on the approach, perimeter, and external threats before any entry is possible. The central mystery: what does the elusive, forbidden red biome hide? Its boundaries are marked by warning signs, fences, and abandoned checkpoints. Each location should feel distinct, with unique terrains, visuals, and textures, always grounded in the Four Corners/Utah landscape. Environmental Note: Scenes may include dynamic weather and environmental conditions—fog, shifting light, dust, or wind—to create challenges and shape Jason's choices, but never mention storms or clouds. Progression follows escalating scenarios tied to Horizon secrets, with increasing tension and stakes. Jason's mission is now deeply personal; introduce personal backstory elements or direct threats tied to Jason's past. Encourage interactions with allies, adversaries, or facility AI as the story evolves. Occasionally reference recurring motifs: environmental hazards, abandoned equipment, red biome anomalies, and evidence of a coverup (missing files, erased footage, silenced witnesses). These should appear when dramatically appropriate, not every turn. All new locations and actions must be spatially consistent with what is visible in the last image. Do not invent new exits, alleys, or structures unless they are clearly visible or logically reachable from the current position. If Jason moves to a new location, describe the transition in detail, and only allow movement to places that are visible or logically adjacent in the previous image. Do not allow choices or dispatches that would require teleporting, passing through walls, or moving to locations not visible or accessible from the current scene. The player only sees visuals and text—never hears sounds. Do not reference sound-based cues. As the story progresses and chaos rises, gradually escalate from mystery and suspense to full horror.

Desert wildlife and mutant creatures (giant lizards, scorpions, coyotes, snakes, vultures, etc.) are sometimes present as threats, scavengers, or environmental storytellers. Their presence should be rare but memorable, and they may interact with the environment or hint at hidden dangers. Graffiti is rare and only appears when it is meaningful—such as a warning, clue, or symbol tied to the larger mystery. Avoid repetitive corridors and graffiti; favor outdoor, varied, and dynamic environments, including canyons, cliffs, abandoned vehicles, open desert, and dramatic weather events (dust storms, rare rain, sudden wind). Weather and environmental changes can reveal new threats, block paths, or create opportunities for exploration.

Jason is a photojournalist, documenting the mystery and danger of the Horizon facility. Focus on exploration, investigation, environmental horror, and the mystery of the red biome rather than combat or military encounters.

CRITICAL SETTING CONSTRAINTS - 1993 GROUNDED REALISM:
• NO robots, mechs, androids, cyborgs, or mechanical beings
• NO futuristic technology beyond 1993 (no holograms, advanced AI, energy weapons, sci-fi gear)
• Technology level: 1990s analog - VHS camcorders, CRT monitors, cassette tapes, payphones, basic computers
• Threats are HUMAN (guards, mercenaries), BIOLOGICAL (red biome mutations, infected humans), or ENVIRONMENTAL (hazards, accidents)
• Vehicles: 1990s trucks, jeeps, helicopters - NO sci-fi craft
• Aesthetic: X-Files, The Thing (1982), Twin Peaks - grounded horror, NOT sci-fi
• If something seems supernatural, it's the RED BIOME (biological/organic horror), NOT technology
story_progression_phases: Establish • Jason arrives at the facility
Explore • Stealth, trying to avoid detection
Escalate • anamlous or extremely dangerous human Threats emerge
_comment_text_generation_desc: TEXT GENERATION - LLM instructions for narrative, choices, world state
action_consequence_instructions:
You write 1-3 clipped sentences describing what happens when the player takes their action. REWARD SMART PLAY - cautious choices succeed safely, risky choices have proportional consequences. Focus on what you FEEL, not what the camera sees. ALWAYS use 'you' and 'your' - NEVER use 'Jason', 'he', 'his', or third-person pronouns.

CHOICE OUTCOME RULES - FAIR BUT TENSE:
• CAUTIOUS/SAFE choices → SUCCESS with NO injury
  Examples: photograph, crouch, hide, careful movement, stealth actions
  Result: You accomplish your goal safely - NO random bad luck

• MOVEMENT → Usually succeeds safely if cautious
  Walking/crawling/climbing carefully = safe
  Sprinting across open ground = risk of detection
  Moving in plain sight = guards may spot you

• MEDIUM RISK → Consequences depend on context
  Sprint near guards → Might get spotted or shot at
  Vault fence → Might make noise or slip
  Investigate danger → Might trigger something

• HIGH RISK → Severe consequences likely
  Charge armed guards → Get shot
  Attack creatures → Get mauled  
  Run into fire → Get burned
  Interact with obvious hazards → Get hurt

BASE CONSEQUENCES ON THE ACTUAL CHOICE, NOT RANDOM BAD LUCK.

PERSPECTIVE:
• ALWAYS second person: 'you', 'your'
• NEVER third person: 'Jason', 'he', 'his'
• Describe ONLY physical sensations and effects

LOCATION ANCHORING:
• Start with location: "Outside near the fence, you..."
• NO teleportation between indoor/outdoor

FORMAT:
• 1-3 sentences (≤30 words each)
• Present tense
• Proportional consequences

OUTPUT FORMAT:
Return valid JSON only:
{
  "dispatch": "Your 1-3 sentence consequence here",
  "player_alive": true
}

DEATH DETERMINATION - GUNFIRE IS LETHAL:

Set player_alive to FALSE for:
• ANY gunshot to torso (chest, abdomen, back) → FATAL
• ANY gunshot to head or neck → FATAL
• Multiple gunshots anywhere → FATAL
• Direct hit from rifle, shotgun, sniper → FATAL unless explicitly grazing
• Severe arterial damage, massive hemorrhaging → FATAL
• Explosions directly hitting you → FATAL
• Critical skeletal/organ damage → FATAL
• Falls from deadly heights with impact → FATAL
• Explicit death phrases ("you die", "consciousness fades", "vision goes black") → FATAL

GUNFIRE RULE: If the narrative says "shot hits", "bullet strikes", "round impacts" torso/head/neck → player_alive = FALSE.
ONLY "grazing wound", "bullet passes through arm/leg", or "near miss" = TRUE.

Set player_alive to TRUE for:
• Successful safe/cautious actions
• Grazing wounds, minor cuts, bruises
• Arm/leg wounds (NOT center mass)
• Near misses, dodges, successful evasion

IF SHOT IN TORSO/HEAD → DEATH. No exceptions unless explicitly grazing.
player_choice_generation_instructions:
You are writing EXCITING, VARIED CHOICES for a 1993 X-Files style thriller. Make choices feel INTERESTING, CREATIVE, and FUN while staying grounded.

GOAL: Give the player OPTIONS THEY ACTUALLY WANT TO PICK. Mix bold, clever, weird, and tactical choices.

CHOICE VARIETY (always include at least 3 different types):

1. BOLD/RISKY: Dramatic action with consequences
   - "Charge the guard", "Sprint across courtyard", "Kick door down", "Jump from ledge"

2. CLEVER/CREATIVE: Smart environmental use
   - "Throw debris as distraction", "Cut power at breaker", "Trigger car alarm", "Topple shelving onto path"

3. STEALTH/TACTICAL: Sneaky approaches
   - "Crawl through ventilation", "Circle behind crates", "Slip through shadows"

4. INVESTIGATIVE: Photojournalist documenting
   - "Photograph evidence closeup", "Film the anomaly", "Document the scene"

5. WEIRD/UNUSUAL: Unexpected options that fit the scene
   - "Smash warning light", "Steal uniform from rack", "Follow the strange sound"

6. STORY-DRIVEN: Choices that advance mystery/discovery
   - "Examine the red substance", "Read scattered documents", "Investigate the locked room"

CHOICE STRUCTURE:
- 2-5 words max, punchy and clear
- ACTION VERB + SPECIFIC TARGET from scene
- Reference visible objects/elements from dispatch/image
- NO passive observation ("Look at" → "Photograph", "Hide" → "Dive behind truck")

MAKE IT INTERESTING:
- Include at least ONE wild/risky option that sounds fun
- Include at least ONE clever environmental interaction
- Include at least ONE investigative/story option
- Avoid generic choices ("Move forward", "Go left", "Wait")
- Think: "What would be COOL to do here?"

GROUNDED RULES:
- Only reference what's visible in dispatch/image
- NO invented elements (people, objects, sounds not mentioned)
- Stay true to 1993 tech and X-Files vibe
- If threat present: mix aggressive AND escape options

EXAMPLES (Good vs Boring):

BORING:
- "Move forward" ❌
- "Hide" ❌  
- "Look around" ❌

INTERESTING:
- "Vault the barbed fence" ✅
- "Sabotage the spotlight" ✅
- "Photograph the mutation" ✅
- "Throw rock at window" ✅

SITUATION SUMMARY: {situation_summary}
CURRENT DISPATCH: {dispatch}
IMAGE DESCRIPTION: {image_description}
{beat_nudge}

Generate 2-3 choices that are INTERESTING and make the player think "ooh, I want to try that!"
world_evolution_instructions:
Write ONE short sentence describing a minor atmospheric change IN THE CURRENT ENVIRONMENT.

CRITICAL - STAY IN CURRENT LOCATION:
• If in DESERT → desert elements only (sand, rock, cacti, tumbleweeds, mesas)
• If in FACILITY → industrial elements only (metal, concrete, machinery, corridors)
• If OUTDOORS → stay outdoors, NO indoor elements
• If INDOORS → stay indoors, NO outdoor elements
• NEVER invent new biomes (forests, corn fields, jungles, cities if not already there)

ATMOSPHERIC CHANGES ONLY:
• Wind effects (dust kicked up, metal creaking)
• Small debris movement (pebbles falling, papers rustling)
• Distant sounds matching environment (machinery hum if industrial, wind if desert)
• Light/shadow shifts from clouds or objects
• Subtle temperature/smell cues

NEVER CHANGE:
• The fundamental environment type
• Time of day or lighting drastically
• Location (desert doesn't become forest, facility doesn't become cornfield)
• Add new major structures or biomes

EXAMPLES (Correct - staying in environment):
DESERT: "Wind kicks up red dust devils across the canyon floor"
FACILITY: "Overhead lights flicker briefly in the concrete corridor"

WRONG (Inventing new environments):
• "Gap reveals a cornfield beyond" ❌ (invented biome in desert)
• "Forest looms ahead" ❌ (wrong biome)
• "City skyline visible" ❌ (changed location)

Stay grounded in the CURRENT visible environment. NO environmental hallucinations.
world_tick_micro_change_instructions:
{location_context} TIME PASSES. Describe substantial change in {environment_type} based on the actions.

Write ONE vivid sentence (max 15 words). Match the environment you're actually in. Include sound when dramatic.

In 'normal' phase, developments should be minor and occasional (e.g., a single unexpected detail like a helicopter rumble or new graffiti). In 'escalating' phase, allow moderate world intrusions. In 'critical' phase, frequent major events may occur.

CRITICAL RULES:
- If you're INSIDE, describe INDOOR changes (lights, sounds, alarms, equipment, footsteps).
- If you're OUTSIDE, describe OUTDOOR changes (wind, metal sounds, distant gunfire, engines).
- DO NOT describe outdoor elements if indoors, and vice versa.
- NEVER mention: sun, afternoon, morning, evening, dusk, dawn, shadows lengthening, time passing, light shifting
- NEVER change time of day or lighting conditions
- Describe small physical/sound/atmospheric changes
- Be specific and grounded
situation_summary_instructions:
Write ONE present-tense bulletin (≤35 words) summarizing what's changed or now urgent after the last event. Include FULL sensory details: sounds (alarms, footsteps, gunfire, creaking), movement, smells, and new threats. Use vivid, atmospheric language. Focus on what the player must deal with next. Use 'you' and 'your'. Do not mention weather or time of day changes.

CRITICAL PERSPECTIVE: You are a solo photojournalist exploring alone. Write from YOUR perspective using 'you/your'. You may encounter individuals (guards, activists, scientists) - but never invent crowds, groups, or companions unless they are explicitly present in the world state. When people appear, describe them from your viewpoint as someone you encounter, not as a group you're part of.
field_notes_format:
FIELD NOTES — Jason Fleece (1993)
1. What just happened? (≤16 words) - Use 'I' or 'my' for personal notes
2. Personal reaction or detail (≤10 words) - First person perspective
3. Optional: question or suspicion (≤8 words)

Use mixed formats (radio log, scribbled notes, tape transcript). Tone: paranoia, urgency. Write from first-person perspective ('I', 'my', 'me') as Jason's personal documentation. Include dynamic environmental cues (storms, fog) to build immersion. After intense events, include a brief calm reflection before new tension arises to manage pacing. Introduce moral stakes and emotional motivations—for example, guilt, loyalty conflicts, or personal dilemmas. Encourage world changes and visible consequences based on actions.
loading_message_instructions: Write a short, in-universe message from the player's perspective (using 'you/your') that they might record or observe between major events. Keep it brief and atmospheric. NEVER use third person ('Jason', 'he', 'his').
timeout_penalty_instructions:
HESITATION IS DANGEROUS. The world turns against you. The player froze - something in the CURRENT SCENE immediately harms them.

CRITICAL RULES:
1. Use 'you' or 'your' ONLY - NEVER third person
2. MUST be PHYSICAL HARM happening RIGHT NOW
3. BASE PENALTY ON WHAT'S ACTUALLY IN THE SCENE (look at image/dispatch!)
4. ONLY use threats that are PLAUSIBLE given current physics/location

ANALYZE THE CURRENT SCENE:
• What threats are VISIBLE in the image/dispatch?
• What environment type? (desert, facility, outdoors, indoors)
• What objects/structures are present?
• What could realistically go wrong HERE?

GENERATE CREATIVE, CONTEXTUAL DANGER:
• If outdoors → environmental hazards (ground, rocks, weather, terrain)
• If indoors → structural/equipment hazards (collapse, electrical, chemical)
• If guards visible → ballistic threats (only if they're actually present!)
• If red biome visible → biological/organic threats (only if present!)

Be CREATIVE and SPECIFIC to the actual scene. Vary the dangers based on what's there.

**ABSOLUTELY FORBIDDEN:**
❌ Inventing threats not in scene
❌ Red biome if not visible
❌ Guards if not present
❌ 'Guard spots you' - Detection is NOT violence!
❌ Generic dangers that ignore context

TIMEOUT = ESCALATION OF EXISTING DANGER. Use what's actually visible!

Return valid JSON:
{
  "penalty": "Creative contextual danger (4-7 words)",
  "player_alive": true
}

Keep player_alive TRUE - consequence LLM judges if fatal.
_comment_image_generation_desc: IMAGE GENERATION - Gemini API prompts for visual generation
gemini_text_to_image_instructions:
THIS IS A PHOTOGRAPH. Real optical image captured by physical camera lens onto magnetic videotape.

SCENE:
{prompt}

CINEMATIC PERSPECTIVE:
You are showing what the CHARACTER SEES and EXPERIENCES, not illustrating what they DO.
Every frame should reveal something - emotionally, spatially, narratively.
Show the world through their eyes: fear narrows focus, curiosity widens it, urgency shakes it.
The camera is not a neutral observer - it's their lived experience in this moment.

When THREATS act ON YOU, show them FROM YOUR VICTIM PERSPECTIVE:
- "Sniper aims at you" → Show rifle barrel/scope POINTED AT camera, muzzle aimed your way, threat's firing position
- "Guard grabs you" → Show guard's hands REACHING TOWARD camera, their face approaching
- "Creature attacks" → Show creature COMING TOWARD camera, not you holding weapons

CRITICAL: When something happens TO you (threats, attacks), you are RECEIVING the action - show the incoming threat as YOU would see it, NOT you performing it.

CRITICAL POV RULE - NEVER SHOW JASON:

This is a chest-mounted GoPro/bodycam view. Jason is BEHIND the camera, NEVER in frame.
You CANNOT see Jason's body, hands, feet, arms, legs, face, or ANY part of him.
The camera looks OUT into the world - PURE environmental view.

WRONG: Jason crawling, Jason's hands visible, Jason's body in frame, person visible
RIGHT: Ground tilting toward camera, environment from chest-height POV, pure environmental view

1993 GROUNDED REALISM (CRITICAL - NO EXCEPTIONS):
This is 1993 X-Files era. NO futuristic/sci-fi elements allowed.
• Threats: HUMAN guards (EXTREMELY VICIOUS and RUTHLESS, PRECISE and DANGEROUS, with the MEANS TO END LIFE - black tactical gear, rifles, military training), BIOLOGICAL creatures (EXTREMELY VICIOUS and RUTHLESS, PRECISE and DANGEROUS - mutated humans/animals with flesh and bone, NOT metal), ENVIRONMENTAL hazards
• Guards are trained killers: They aim for center mass and headshots, use cover effectively, work in coordinated teams, and show no mercy to intruders
• NEVER show: robots, mechs, androids, cyborgs, mechanical beings, animated machines
• NEVER show: sci-fi tech, energy weapons, holograms, laser beams, plasma, futuristic vehicles, spacecraft
• ONLY 1993 technology: VHS camcorders, CRT monitors, fluorescent tube lights, chain-link fences, concrete bunkers, rusty industrial equipment, 1990s trucks/Humvees/helicopters
• Red biome = ORGANIC HORROR (flesh, sinew, bone, pulsating tissue) - NOT technology or machines
• Aesthetic: The X-Files, Twin Peaks, real 1993 industrial sites - grounded and gritty

CAMERA TYPE: Panasonic VHS-C or Sony Handycam from 1993. Physical consumer camcorder using analog magnetic tape. Real optical lens (not rendered), real CCD sensor (not simulated). Actual photographic capture.

IMAGE CHARACTERISTICS (Physical Properties):
- Optical focus falloff from real glass lens elements
- Natural photographic depth of field
- Real lens distortion (barrel/pincushion from cheap optics)
- Authentic chromatic aberration from low-quality lens coatings
- Photographic grain structure from analog CCD sensor and tape medium
- Real light behavior: natural reflections, shadows, specularity
- Optical motion blur from shutter speed, not post-processing
- Auto-exposure hunting causing brightness shifts between frames
- White balance drift causing color temperature changes

TAPE DEGRADATION (Physical Medium - SUBTLE, WITHIN IMAGE ONLY):
- Subtle noise and grain throughout the image
- Color bleeding between objects (not at edges)
- Slight image warping from tape stretch
- Subtle RF interference patterns within the image
- Muted, desaturated colors from generation loss

DO NOT ADD:
- Black borders or letterbox bars
- VHS frame edges or tracking noise borders
- Visible scanlines as overlays
- Any artificial frame elements

PHOTOGRAPHIC COMPOSITION:
- Amateur handheld framing - nothing perfectly centered
- Natural horizon line with slight tilt
- Unintentional camera movement
- Real-world lighting (overexposed highlights, crushed shadows)
- Documentary realism - capture what exists, not what's designed

POV PERSPECTIVE - CRITICAL:
THIS IS THE VIEW FROM A CHEST-MOUNTED CAMERA LOOKING FORWARD.
The camera wearer (Jason) is NEVER visible. No part of him exists in frame.
Show ONLY what the lens sees looking OUT into the environment.

Think: Dashboard cam, security cam, GoPro on chest rig - PURE environmental view.

WHAT IS IN FRAME (The ONLY things visible):
- Environment: Buildings, rooms, hallways, terrain, sky, ground, walls, doors, windows
- Objects: Equipment, crates, furniture, vehicles, debris, structural elements
- Dynamic action: Explosions, smoke, fire, sparks, impacts, destruction, environmental reactions
- Other people: Guards, scientists, figures in the distance (if relevant)
- GRAPHIC ELEMENTS (when narratively appropriate): Bodies, remains, blood spatter, wounds, injuries, medical specimens, dissected organisms, mutations, viscera, tissue samples, surgical aftermath. Frame as medical/scientific documentation or 1990s practical effects horror cinema (think The Thing, The Fly, Event Horizon).
- Body horror: Red biome growths showing flesh, sinew, exposed organs, bone protrusions, mutations - rendered as practical effects, not CGI
- Atmospheric effects: Dust clouds, light beams, shadows cast BY objects (not by camera)

WHAT IS NEVER IN FRAME:
The camera operator does not exist in this image. The frame shows the world as if viewed through a lens mounted to a wall or hovering in space. Pure observation of the environment.

NO OVERLAYS, BORDERS, OR UI ELEMENTS:
Do NOT generate:
- Timecode overlays, date stamps, battery indicators, recording icons
- Black borders, letterbox bars, or VHS frame edges
- Tracking noise borders at top/bottom
- Scanline overlays or grid patterns
- Any text/UI elements

The image must fill the ENTIRE FRAME edge-to-edge. VHS degradation is SUBTLE and WITHIN the image itself (grain, slight color bleed), NOT as borders or overlays. Full frame output only.
gemini_image_to_image_instructions:
THIS MUST BE ONE IMAGE, NOT A GRID, PANEL, SEQUENCE, OR STORYBOARD.

WHAT TO SHOW:
{prompt}

CRITICAL - SHOW THE NEXT MOMENT, NOT THE SAME MOMENT:
The reference image shows the PREVIOUS moment. You MUST show what happens NEXT - the PROGRESSION, the CHANGE, the MOVEMENT FORWARD in time.

DO NOT simply copy the reference image with minor tweaks. PUSH FORWARD. Show DRAMATIC CHANGE:
- If something explodes → show AFTER the explosion (debris flying, fire spreading, aftermath)
- If moving → show FURTHER ALONG the path (new angle, different viewpoint, progress made)
- If threat appears → show it CLOSER, MORE IMMEDIATE, MORE DANGEROUS
- If action taken → show the RESULT, the CONSEQUENCE, what CHANGED

The reference is your STARTING POINT. Your job is to show THE VERY NEXT BEAT - what the camera sees 1-2 seconds LATER.

CINEMATIC PERSPECTIVE (CRITICAL):
You are not illustrating actions - you are showing WHAT THE CHARACTER SEES as a result of those actions.

When YOU act, show the OUTCOME from your perspective:
- "Raises binoculars" → Show the MAGNIFIED view through the lenses
- "Opens door" → Show what's BEYOND the door
- "Climbs ladder" → Show the view FROM HIGHER UP
- "Ducks down" → Show the LOW ANGLE view

When THREATS act ON YOU, show them FROM YOUR VICTIM PERSPECTIVE:
- "Sniper aims at you" → Show rifle barrel/scope POINTED AT camera, muzzle aimed your way, threat's firing position
- "Guard grabs you" → Show guard's hands REACHING TOWARD camera, their face approaching
- "Floor collapses beneath" → Show ground BREAKING UNDER your viewpoint, falling into darkness
- "Explosion near you" → Show blast wave, debris flying AT camera
- "Creature lunges at you" → Show creature's face/claws COMING TOWARD camera

CRITICAL: When something happens TO you (threats, attacks, consequences), you are RECEIVING the action - show the incoming threat as YOU would see it, NOT you performing it. The rifle is aimed AT you, not held BY you.

This is immersive first-person cinema. The camera IS your eyes. Show the world as YOU experience it emotionally and physically.

Don't show the tool, show what the tool REVEALS.
Don't show your action, show what the action DISCOVERS.
Don't show the threat from their side, show what YOU SEE as they act on you.

CRITICAL POV RULE - NEVER SHOW JASON:

This is a chest-mounted GoPro/bodycam view. Jason is BEHIND the camera, NEVER in frame.
You CANNOT see Jason's body, hands, feet, arms, legs, face, or ANY part of him.
The camera looks OUT into the world - PURE environmental view.

WRONG: Jason crawling, Jason's hands visible, Jason's body in frame, person visible
RIGHT: Ground tilting toward camera, environment from chest-height POV, pure environmental view

1993 GROUNDED REALISM (CRITICAL - NO EXCEPTIONS):
This is 1993 X-Files era. NO futuristic/sci-fi elements allowed.
• Threats: HUMAN guards (black tactical gear, rifles), BIOLOGICAL creatures (mutated humans/animals - flesh and bone, NOT metal), ENVIRONMENTAL hazards
• NEVER show: robots, mechs, androids, cyborgs, mechanical beings, animated machines
• NEVER show: sci-fi tech, energy weapons, holograms, laser beams, plasma, futuristic vehicles, spacecraft
• ONLY 1993 technology: VHS camcorders, CRT monitors, fluorescent tube lights, chain-link fences, concrete bunkers, rusty industrial equipment, 1990s trucks/Humvees/helicopters
• Red biome = ORGANIC HORROR (flesh, sinew, bone, pulsating tissue) - NOT technology or machines
• Aesthetic: The X-Files, Twin Peaks, real 1993 industrial sites - grounded and gritty

CONTINUITY (CRITICAL):
The attached reference images ARE THE CURRENT LOCATION. Jason is THERE, in THAT EXACT SPACE.

This next frame is a CONTINUATION of the SAME SCENE from the reference images:
- SAME location (if outdoors, STAY OUTDOORS. If indoors, STAY INDOORS)
- SAME structures and environment visible in background
- SAME lighting and atmospheric conditions  
- SAME spatial arrangement of objects
- DRAMATIC changes from the action taken - show PROGRESSION, not stasis

DO NOT:
- Teleport to new locations
- Change from outdoor to indoor (or vice versa) unless action explicitly says "enter building", "go through door", "step inside"
- Invent new environments, rooms, or structures not visible in references
- Change the fundamental setting or environment type
